meaning_mnemonic: Regardless of whether or not you wear a <radical>hat</radical> while you <radical>jackhammer</radical>, you’re going to have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
meaning_hint: The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
reading_mnemonic: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ) stand. Having a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.
reading_hint: Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> with the <radical>old</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> is the one who has said many things. That makes them different from everyone, an <kanji>individual</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine that leader's old mouth saying things that make the old man stand apart from the others. They are individual from everyone else.
reading_mnemonic: As an <kanji>individual</kanji>, one must teach all the <reading>子</reading>s (こ) their way. Their individual way.
reading_hint: "You must be your own individual. Don't be a sheeple," he says to the 子s.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone stabbed the <radical>leader</radical> <radical>mole</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>overthrow</kanji> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
meaning_hint: Imagine a mole sneaking up behind the leader mole and stabbing him with a knife. This type of overthrowing of leadership feels familiar to you. Maybe this has happened before in the past?
reading_mnemonic: Where do leaders get <kanji>overthrow</kanji>n the most? In <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in とうきょう.
reading_hint: Picture this like an exaggerated reenactment on the History channel. Leader after leader of とうきょう gets overthrown and replaced with the next guy. It never stops. (Until the end of the Edo period, I guess.)

meaning_mnemonic: You hit your <radical>head</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and a <radical>knife</radical> falls out and <kanji>stab</kanji>s you. Ow! What the heck?! What was a knife doing in that tree?
meaning_hint: Imagine the pain and confusion of being stabbed by a violent tree. You hit your head on the tree again, as if to test it, and again a knife falls out and stabs you. Oh, so it's a stabbing tree, is it? That does it!
reading_mnemonic: There's nothing more dangerous than a tree that likes to <kanji>stab</kanji>, so you get your <reading>saw</reading> (さ) and start to saw it down. Trees that stab get sawed!
reading_hint: Feel the grain of the saw's wooden handle in your bare hand. As the saw bites into tree bark, a retaliatory rain of knives comes stabbing down around you. But you don't even flinch. You will saw this stabbing tree down.

meaning_mnemonic: Hanging off the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> is a <radical>sun</radical> worshipping <radical>child</radical> with a <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries at the sun for cursing him to this cruel fate. Even the thickness of his unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to pull himself back up.
meaning_hint: I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
reading_mnemonic: The child's <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow can't wait any longer and gives up. It hops off the child's face and says, "Hey dude, I'll be <reading>at Sue's</reading> (あつ)." She'll appreciate my thick, luxuriousness more than a weakling like you.
reading_hint: I guess if you want to go see that thick, beautiful unibrow you'll have to go see it at Sue's now. What's that? Oh, don't worry about the child. It uh. It's probably at Sue's too! Maybe... (or dead).

meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>mouth</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this distressed and troubled person. Taste the taste of sap and bark in your mouth as you nom on the tree with all your might.
reading_mnemonic: You thought you were the most <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled <reading>con</reading>dor (こん). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day.
reading_hint: Picture a very distressed condor watching you munch your mouth all over its tree house. You've made a condor enemy this day.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> under a <radical>cliff</radical> is going to be under a lot of <kanji>pressure</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine being down there with all that dirt. Imagine feeling the pressure closing in around you. It's so hard to breathe... h... help!
reading_mnemonic: The dirt being crushed under this <kanji>pressure</kanji> can't help but react by sneezing out, "<reading>Achoo</reading> (あつ)!" This sneeze-inducing pressure probably has something to do with where earthquakes come from.
reading_hint: Imagine you're the dirt being pressed from every direction, the pressure so strong, and it squeezes an ACHOO right out of you.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sticks a <radical>stick</radical> into the <radical>dirt</radical> to see what might <kanji>exist</kanji> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a narwhal sticking a stick, and maybe even its horn too, into the dirt on land. It needs to know if life exists outside of the ocean for sure.
reading_mnemonic: The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could <kanji>exist</kanji> outside of its world. It pulls out a <reading>xy</reading>lophone (ざい) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it.
reading_hint: Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone and think about what exists in this world. It's a sad song, you realize.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> is upon your <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <kanji>dream</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Watch yourself sleeping. Then, a net of flowers appear on your forehead as you start to dream.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dream</kanji> about cows saying "<reading>moo</reading> (む), moo, moo!"
reading_hint: While still dreaming, you say "moo" out loud too. "Moooo!"

meaning_mnemonic: You place a <radical>cross</radical> on a <radical>Wolverine</radical> <radical>woman</radical>. She's gone now, but she was once your <kanji>wife</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Oh, how you miss your Wolverine woman and her long, sharp claws… Now all you've got left to remember her by is this cross. Your poor, poor wife.
reading_mnemonic: Wait a minute… She can't be dead because your <kanji>wife</kanji> is a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい)! How could you forget?!
reading_hint: All your wife needs is a little cyborg tune-up. Bionic brain here, some new claws there. Yep, your cy-wife's as good as new.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>woman</radical> sees the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, she feels a strong feeling of <kanji>dislike</kanji>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself feeling this strong dislike towards the Mona Lisa. She gets all the attention and you get none. It’s not fair and you’re upset.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dislike</kanji> the Mona Lisa so much you hire <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai to cut her up.
reading_hint: Ken walks slowly toward the Mona Lisa, dislike shines in his eyes, but then! He falls for her too. No! Ken, destroy her!

meaning_mnemonic: You slip off the <radical>roof</radical>, your <radical>life</radical> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <radical>mouth</radical> on the ground causing some serious <kanji>damage</kanji>. Oof, this is a really bad <kanji>injury</kanji>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine that moment as you fall off the roof. In slow motion you can see the roof moving away, you see yourself as a little kid, a teen, an adult, then BAM you've injured your mouth. Ow ow ow!
reading_mnemonic: As you try to assess the <kanji>damage</kanji>, you hear someone shout, "<reading>Guy</reading> (がい), hey, you okay, guy?" They run up to you, but your mouth is too <kanji>damage</kanji>d, you can't respond. "Okay guy, I'm gonna call you Guy now. Let's get you to the hospital."
reading_hint: No matter how much you try to wave your hands and gesture, they keep calling you Guy. It's really annoying, actually, because you aren't a guy and you aren't Guy either. But your mouth is too damaged for you to tell him.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>nine</radical> <radical>flag</radical>s. With these nine flags you take them one by one and put them up your <kanji>butt</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking these nine flags... count 'em... and putting them up your butt. With each one that's up there it gets harder and harder to fit the next one in.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have nine flags inside your <kanji>butt</kanji>, you have to get them out. But, you don't know how to. So you ask <reading>Siri</reading> (しり), "how do I get nine flags out of my butt?"
reading_hint: In your head, doing the Siri voice, come up with an answer for your nine flags in the butt predicament.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <radical>fur</radical> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <kanji>tail</kanji>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
meaning_hint: What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
reading_mnemonic: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge <reading>bee</reading>hive (び)! These bees made their home under the <kanji>tail</kanji>! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.
reading_hint: See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> sits with <radical>twenty</radical> little <kanji>contraptions</kanji>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.
meaning_hint: Can you even imagine twenty completely unique contraptions? Why don't you try, just for fun.
reading_mnemonic: You want to know what these <kanji>contraptions</kanji> are for, so you ask. The drunkard says, "These are <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) contraptions *urp* they're for your uh *blarp* kayak... things."
reading_hint: "Kayak contraptions" is pretty vague, but you do have a kayak, so you're tempted anyway. If only you could figure out what each contraption did so you could justify buying some.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> is the kind of <radical>person</radical> who would <radical>poop</radical> two times under a <radical>tree</radical> before using a <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet. There’s a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a portable machine toilet right there?
reading_mnemonic: Oh, I see – the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn’t have the <reading>key</reading> (き). If he had a <kanji>machine</kanji> like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he’s reduced to pooping under the tree instead.
reading_hint: Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn’t sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flood</radical> and a <radical>fire</radical>! At the same time? This is a <kanji>disaster</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Imagine a disaster so bad that there are floods AND fires. That's too much!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>disaster</kanji> was caused by your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい)! It's malfunctioning, running around leaking large amounts of water and breathing fire. I guess you didn't work out all the kinks before you let it roam wild.
reading_hint: You better figure out a way to stop your cyborg from causing more disasters like this. Fix it now, or you're gonna be in big trouble.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>animal</radical> kingdom, a <radical>snake</radical> is the most likely to commit a <kanji>crime</kanji>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.
meaning_hint: Picture a snake as a hardened criminal. See this snake with many prison tattoos and muscles from working out in his jail cell. Hear the snake hissing as it slithers about to commit yet another crime.
reading_mnemonic: This snake has evaded the law for too long. It’s time for a true hero to put an end to its <kanji>crime</kanji> spree. Enter <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. Han Solo is the only man strong and brave enough to put an end to this snake and his crime filled ways.
reading_hint: Now see Han Solo doing battle with the snake (cue Star Wars music). The snake hisses and lunges at Han, but Han shoots the snake and it’s incapacitated. Smell the smell of scorched snake flesh in your nose.

meaning_mnemonic: Sitting on the <radical>lid</radical> of a toilet, you're praying your <radical>poop</radical> <radical>explosion</radical> will be flushed away, beseeching the <radical>cross</radical> decorating the bathroom wall. The poop needs to be one hundred <kanji>percent</kanji> flushed away because you're on a date, and you don't want even one percent of your explosion left for them to see.
meaning_hint: You take a peek under the lid to check, and your poop explosion is one hundred percent gone! Phew!
reading_mnemonic: It was extra important that there was zero <kanji>percent</kanji> poop left, because you're not on a date just anywhere, you're at the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ)!
reading_hint: Look around you at the classy surroundings of the Ritz Hotel bathroom. You feel one hundred percent relieved now, and ready to enjoy your date at the Ritz!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on the <radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Life</radical> and <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it! In your despair, you throw all your <kanji>property</kanji> off the cliff too.
meaning_hint: The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets towards the ground below.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>give birth</kanji>, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん)! He caught your baby! And all your <kanji>property</kanji>.
reading_hint: Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. You can keep all my property and give it away as presents.

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>stone</radical> to the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>turkey</radical>. It is <kanji>certain</kanji> that you will damage it.
meaning_hint: Try hitting a sponge on a turkey's forehead. Not certain. Now a stone. <kanji>Certain</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're killing this turkey, and you need to make sure he's dead for <kanji>certain</kanji>. The reason you need to make sure this turkey is dead is because of the <reading>cock</reading> (かく) in your life. Male chickens get really jealous when turkeys are around.
reading_hint: As you smash the stone into the turkey's forehead, yell out "This is for you, my cock! THIS IS FOR YOU!" Your cock lover watches from the shadows.

meaning_mnemonic: Tying a <radical>thread</radical> to a <radical>tombstone</radical> each year will help you <kanji>manage</kanji> the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>. That way you’ll know how many years you <kanji>pass through</kanji>, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself coming back to the same tombstone each passing year and tying a new thread to it. You're trying to manage these feelings by keeping track of how much time passes.
reading_mnemonic: Dealing with the <kanji>passage of time</kanji> can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well?
reading_hint: Maybe this is your future tombstone, and eating cake each year is a preemptive celebration of your death day! Ooh, what a spooky theory.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>net</radical> around a <radical>criminal</radical> to show their <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.
meaning_hint: Imagine throwing a net around someone you think, no, you know is guilty of doing something bad to you. It feels pretty nice.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>guilt</kanji> shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen <reading>xy</reading>lophone (ざい) out of their back pocket.
reading_hint: Woah! The xylophone is huge, how did they... well whatever, you definitely have proof that they're guilty now and the cops should be here any minute to take your criminal catch.

meaning_mnemonic: Wash your<radical>self</radical> with a <radical>big</radical> bar of soap if you're <kanji>stinking</kanji> everything up.
meaning_hint: Seriously. If you or someone else is stinking to high heaven, embrace a big bar of self care.
reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>stinking</kanji> up the room because you spent your day rolling in <reading>草</reading> (くさ). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that 草 too...
reading_hint: Imagine trying to use a big bar of soap on yourself to get the stinky 草 off. But it's not working... the 草 stink is SO STRONG!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> loses its <radical>skin</radical> as a part of the damage it <kanji>incur</kanji>s after death. That's why the spirit goes on looking for new skin to <kanji>cover</kanji> itself with.
meaning_hint: Some spirits get mad when they lose their skin, so living humans have to incur their wrath as the spirits search for more skin to cover themselves with.
reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>incur</kanji> the wrath of an angry spirit it'll try to <kanji>cover</kanji> itself with your skin, and you'll feel your skin <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) up.
reading_hint: It feels like your skin is burning a little. You're about to incur the same kind of damage the spirit did when it lost its skin cover. Oww owww!

meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>valley</radical>, spirits are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it.
meaning_hint: Just picture those forest spirits from that famous anime film. The woods are full of them. An abundant valley of spirits.
reading_mnemonic: In spirit valley, it's not just spirits that are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. There is an abundance of <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) as well.
reading_hint: Imagine an abundant number of spirits and youths hanging out, drinking microbrews and eating avocado toast. Spirit Valley is a weird place.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical>, throwing your <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> in front of the <radical>bookshelf</radical>, "I have a <kanji>theory</kanji>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!
meaning_hint: This theory you've thought of is great, it's going to change everything!
reading_mnemonic: "What is your theory, <reading>Ron</reading> (ろん)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort.
reading_hint: "Ron? Ron, what's your theory? What's your theory, Ron?" Hermione asks over and over. But you freeze. You don't remember who you are. "Hermione, I have a theory that I was just a person learning Japanese, and not a magical boy at all." "Shut up Ron, that's a stupid theory," she replies.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> is <radical>righteousness</radical>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>discussion</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a deliberation with some other people. They think what they're saying is right, and it drives you mad. Then you realize that you're doing the same thing.
reading_mnemonic: What are you in <kanji>deliberation</kanji> about? Whether or not to send some poor soul to the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). "I think he should go," you say. "I don't think he should," says another. This <kanji>deliberation</kanji> is going nowhere...
reading_hint: Imagine how the deliberation concludes. Then, at the end, someone says "This deliberation is over! We have decided to _________" (in regards to the guillotine).

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>building</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> you want to go it will <kanji>prevent</kanji> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!
meaning_hint: There's a building right there. Try to go that direction. Oh, did the building prevent you? Told you so.
reading_mnemonic: The building is <kanji>prevent</kanji>ing you from going the right direction, so you pull a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further.
reading_hint: Your bowling antics are now preventing a bunch of people from going the directions they want to go. Nice job.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Chinese</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult.
meaning_hint: Try and picture a Chinese turkey in your brain. Now imagine yourself trying to catch it, but you just can’t. It’s too difficult. The Chinese turkey is too elusive.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know the actual reason Chinese turkey are so <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find? It’s because they’re all made out of <reading>Naan</reading> (なん). Of course they’re elusive when they blend in so well with all the other Naan!
reading_hint: Picture yourself entering a bakery, frantically scouring through all the Naan in an attempt to find one that’s actually a Chinese turkey. "WHERE ARE THE TURKEYS?", you scream, to everyone else’s bewilderment. Those elusive, difficult to find Chinese Naan turkeys…

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> causes a <radical>landslide</radical> that causes an <kanji>earthquake</kanji>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <kanji>shake</kanji>s and <kanji>quake</kanji>s.
meaning_hint: Picture this happening in real time. First it starts to rain really hard, then the ground starts to shift and run, then everything is shaking and quaking so violently it's an earthquake!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> shakes you so violently that you fall over, banging your <reading>shin</reading> (しん) on the coffee table. The edge of the coffee table is very sharp, so it cuts into your shin pretty badly.
reading_hint: You grab your shin, but the earthquake shakes the coffee table toward you to hit your shin yet again! Ow ow ow stop!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fly</radical> radical and the <kanji>fly</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>fly</kanji>, you generate a lot of <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.
reading_hint: You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.
